title: Hi, I‚Äôm Yiran Hu
text:
Hi, I‚Äôm Yiran Hu



Yiran Hu


I am a graduate student in Systems Engineering with a background in Computer Science and data analysis.
‚ù§Ô∏è I work at the intersection of data science and computer programming, and I enjoy taking on a wide range of problems rather than staying within a single discipline. I am motivated by curiosity and enjoy learning from different industries and people, as I believe this breadth helps me build stronger judgment and opens up more possibilities for my future work.


üîç What I Work On

Data analysis & visualization ‚Äî transforming complex datasets into clear, actionable insights (Python, Tableau)
Applied research & computational modeling ‚Äî translating scientific and technical concepts into working systems (simulation, ECG)
Web development & content systems ‚Äî building and maintaining real-world websites with sustainable content workflows (WordPress, HTML/CSS)
Machine learning & data analysis ‚Äî exploring models to identify patterns and risk signals in large-scale data
Technical communication & storytelling ‚Äî presenting technical work clearly to non-technical audiences through visuals and narrative
Human-centered design & accessibility ‚Äî designing usable, inclusive interfaces grounded in real user needs (Figma, HCI)




üìÇ Featured Work
Please visit the Projects page to explore selected projects, including:
- Interactive data dashboards analyzing student academic outcomes.
- A community service website redesigned and maintained using WordPress.
- A mobile recipe app prototype designed with accessibility in mind.



üîó Connect With Me

GitHub: https://github.com/CenlingH

LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/yiran-h-942815293/

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/yiranhu1225/

Email: yiranhu@seas.upenn.edu

title: Resume
text:
University of Pennsylvania
M.S.E. in Systems Engineering
Philadelphia, PA | Aug 2025 ‚Äì May 2027 (Expected)
University of Illinois Urbana‚ÄìChampaign
Exchange Program, College of Liberal Arts & Sciences
Urbana‚ÄìChampaign, IL | Aug 2023 ‚Äì May 2024
ShanghaiTech University
B.E. in Computer Science and Technology
Shanghai, China | Sep 2021 ‚Äì Jun 2025






Applied Technologies for Learning in the Arts & Sciences
Champaign, IL | May 2024 ‚Äì Aug 2024

Researched on factors such as family income and regional disparities to identify causes of academic struggle and dropout, providing insight for early intervention and policy suggestions.
Built and explored various machine learning models, including Random Forest, Neural Networks, and XGBoost in Python using data from 90,000+ students and 250 features; applied data cleaning, feature selection, and classification algorithms to improve prediction accuracy by 15%.
Developed an interactive Tableau dashboard with regional heatmaps visualizing student performance by location, and presented findings to stakeholders with Python visualization tools such as Matplotlib.





Community Service Center of Northern Champaign County
Champaign, IL | Jan 2024 ‚Äì May 2024

Redesigned the community website using WordPress, incorporating an event calendar and bilingual functionality to improve readability, accessibility, and visibility of public programs.
Maintained a dynamic online presence by creating new pages with detailed images and descriptions with HTML and CSS; Enhancing visual appeal and increasing participation in key services like the food pantry.
Analyzed donation trends and refined the donation system to better support the center‚Äôs charitable services, resulting in more efficient resource allocation and increased donor satisfaction.








Tools: Python, Tableau
Champaign, IL | Jan 2024 ‚Äì May 2024

Performed comprehensive data analysis on a 303-patient clinical dataset to identify significant predictors of heart disease, providing data-driven insights to support medical research and diagnostic decision-making.
Utilized Python libraries including Pandas, NumPy, Matplotlib, and Seaborn for data cleaning, statistical computation, and exploratory visualization to ensure analytical rigor and reproducibility.
Developed interactive dashboards in Tableau to visualize correlations between clinical symptoms (e.g., atypical angina) and heart disease risk.
Reported analytical findings and model interpretations to clinical stakeholders, translating statistical outcomes into actionable insights for early intervention strategies and future research direction.





Tools: Java, MySQL
Philadelphia, PA | Aug 2025 ‚Äì Present

Developed core backend services in Java for a transaction capture and execution pipeline, supporting data integrity, correctness, and operational reliability.
Designed and managed MySQL and MongoDB data stores to handle high-volume records, emphasizing schema consistency, data quality, and query reliability.
Contributed to an iterative development workflow using Git and Maven, incorporating testing, code reviews, and incremental improvements to enhance system maintainability and stability.





Tools: Figma
Champaign, IL | Jan 2024 ‚Äì May 2024

Designed a mobile recipe app prototype to help users find meals based on time, cost, dietary preferences, and available ingredients
Conducted thorough analysis of existing recipe apps to inform feature selection and usability decisions
Created end-to-end user flows including recipe discovery, shopping lists, and user profiles
Integrated accessibility considerations, such as large touch targets, consistent layouts, and reduced cognitive load








Research Assistant
Shanghai, China | Nov 2024 ‚Äì Jun 2025

Built a GPU-accelerated 3D cardiac electrophysiology simulator in C/CUDA, modeling large-scale myocardial grids and parallelizing cell-state updates for high-resolution simulations.
Extended a cellular automata framework to explicitly model depolarization and repolarization, redesigning state-transition rules and calibrating timing parameters to better reflect physiological behavior.
Analyzed electrical conduction and propagation pathways across atria, ventricles, and the conduction system, examining how activation timing and conduction delays shape characteristic ECG waveforms.
Implemented full 12-lead ECG computation and an end-to-end simulation workflow, supporting pacemaker stimulation and arrhythmia scenarios (e.g., PVC, atrial flutter) with visualization for analysis.








China Thinks Big National Forum
Shanghai, China | Feb 2025 ‚Äì Mar 2025

Supported on-site operations for a national academic forum with 1,900+ students, faculty, and guests
Hosted high school paper presentation and defense sessions, coordinating judges and managing time flow
Facilitated a leadership simulation workshop, engaging directly with students and promoting inclusive participation

title: My Projects
text:
Tools: Python, Tableau
Type: Data Analytics Internship


This project focuses on analyzing UIUC student datasets to uncover patterns related to academic performance and student outcomes. The goal was not only to analyze the data and find students at risk of dropping out, but to translate complex academic information into clear, interactive visual insights that can be understood by both technical and non-technical audiences.




Cleaned and validated institutional student data, ensuring consistency across academic records

Researched and analyzed key academic indicators such as GPA, academic standing, social economic status, and geographic attributes that may influence student success
Explored patterns in unfinished students and academic risk levels through exploratory analysis

Built interactive Tableau dashboards to allow users to explore trends and compare student outcomes dynamically





Student academic outcomes exhibit clear geographic disparities across regions
Students from areas with less access to educational resources show a higher proportion of unfinished enrollment
These regions also contain a larger share of students in poor academic standing, including probation-level status
The coexistence of unfinished enrollment and academic risk suggests that structural and regional factors may play an important role in student performance




Rather than presenting static charts, this project emphasizes data storytelling and clarity.
By allowing users to interact with the dashboard, researchers and educators can: - Explore academic patterns independently across different student groups
- Identify students who may be at potential academic risk and require additional attention
- Better understand how multiple factors relate to student progress and outcomes




üëâ Interactive Tableau Dashboard:
View on Tableau Public




Geographic distribution of student academic status and unfinished enrollment across regions.







Tools: WordPress, HTML, CSS
Type: Web Development Internship


Redesigned and improved a community service organization‚Äôs website to make key resources easier to find and to support a broader audience with bilingual content. The focus was on real-world usability: helping visitors quickly locate services, learn how to volunteer, and complete donations with fewer steps.




Rebuilt the site structure and navigation, reorganizing content so visitors can easily locate key information such as services, events, and volunteering opportunities

Redesigned and updated core pages, including Service and Volunteer sections, to improve clarity and usability

Implemented a bilingual language experience (English / Spanish) and maintained content consistency across both versions

Created and maintained an interactive event calendar, enabling staff to freely add, edit, and remove events

Designed event pop-up interactions that display event details on hover, improving event discoverability

Regularly updated event content and media, including adding new activities, descriptions, and photos to keep the site current





Improved information accessibility for diverse community members, including bilingual audiences

Increased visibility of community events and activities through a clear, regularly updated event calendar

Delivered a more consistent and maintainable website structure to support ongoing content updates





Archived version of the live production website:
View via Internet Archive


Note: The website has since been updated and maintained by other contributors after my internship.
This archived version reflects the site structure and content during my contribution period.
Some dynamic elements (e.g., event calendar interactions or gallery images) may not fully load due to archiving limitations.

Event page (captured during normal operation):



Event calendar page with interactive event details and hover pop-ups.







Tools: Figma
Type: UX / UI Design ¬∑ Human-Computer Interaction


QuickPlate is a mobile recipe application designed to help users quickly find meals that match their time constraints, budget, dietary preferences, and available ingredients.
The project focuses on reducing the cognitive and emotional burden of meal planning, especially for busy students and individuals with limited time.



This app was designed around realistic, everyday scenarios, such as: - A student returning home after work who wants to cook using only the ingredients already available - Users with limited time who need recipes filtered by total cooking time - Individuals looking to explore new dishes without complicated preparation steps
QuickPlate addresses these needs by allowing users to filter recipes by ingredients, cooking time, cost, time of day, and dietary preferences (e.g., vegetarian or vegan).




Conducted analysis of existing recipe apps to identify gaps in usability and feature focus

Prioritized simplicity and quick decision-making over excessive recipe complexity

Designed user flows that support:

Saving and editing personal recipes

Generating a combined ingredient list that functions as a shopping list

Tracking cooked meals and favorited recipes through a user profile





Accessibility was a core consideration throughout the design:
- Mobility impairments: Large buttons, simplified interactions, and layouts optimized for one-handed use
- Cognitive accessibility: Consistent layouts, clear iconography, and reduced visual clutter to lower cognitive load
- Neurodiversity & mental health: Calm color palette, no flashing elements, and predictable navigation to reduce stress and anxiety
These choices were made to ensure the app is usable, welcoming, and easy to learn for a wide range of users.



The final Figma prototype demonstrates: - A complete end-to-end user flow from recipe discovery to meal tracking
- Clear information hierarchy and intuitive navigation
- A design that balances functionality, accessibility, and visual clarity




üëâ Interactive Figma Prototype:
View Prototype




QuickPlate mobile app prototype showcasing recipe filtering and user flow.



üé• Design Walkthrough Video

The following video presents a walkthrough of the QuickPlate prototype, including design motivation, challenges encountered, key decisions, and scenario-based demonstrations of how users interact with the app. üòÜ
